experimental_sections:
Materials and methods 431 
Strains and culturing conditions  432 
For the initial tests, Streptomyces coelicolor M145 [28] and Actinobacteria from the MBT strain 433 
collection of the Institute of Biology Leiden were used for screening. These strains were isolated from 434 
the Himalaya mountains, Qinling mountains, Cheverny and Grenouillere France and the Netherlands 435 
[42]. The Streptomyces plates were incubated at 30 °C for 10 days or longer before investigating the 436 
BHET degradation. E. coli was grown on Luria-Burtani (LB) agar or in LB cultures overnight at 37 °C.  437 
Routine Streptomyces manipulation, growth and preparation of spore stocks was performed according 438 
to the Streptomyces manual  [53]. Spore suspensions were obtained by growing the strains on Soy 439 
Flour Mannitol agar (SFM [54]) until sporulation.  440 
 441 
Homology search 442 
Potential homologs of the PETase Ideonella sakaiensis (Uniprot A0A0K8P6T7 (PETH_IDESA)) in the 443 
Actinobacterial genomes were identified by performing a BLASTp for the genome of Streptomyces 444 
coelicolor (NCBI 100226) [35].  BLASTp was run in the default setting. The hits were ranked based on 445 
their BLAST score, their query cover, their percent identity and the presence of the catalytic triad and 446 
substrate binding site. 447 
 448 
Bulk screens 449 
The strains are inoculated on the plates using the stamping method. A stamp fitting a 96-wells plate 450 
was autoclaved, placed in the stamping device and placed in the 96 wells plate, containing 100 μ l of 451 
each spore stock in separate wells, and stamped on the plates of interest. Each spot contained 452 
approximately 2 μl of spore solution. The plates were grown for 10 days at 30 °C. the spore plates 453 
were stored at -20 °C.  454 
 455 
Plate assays 456 
Plate assays were performed using minimal medium plates with different types of agars. Upon media 457 
selection, Streptomyces minimal medium (StrepMM [53]) Difco agar was chosen as standard condition 458 
[55]. Plates and additives are described in table 1. Bis(2-hydroxyethyl) terephthalate (BHET) provided 459 
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted November 9, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.11.08.566248doi: bioRxiv preprint 
by Sigma (Cas: 959-26-2, PN 465151), N-acetyl glucosamine (GlcNAc) provided by Sigma (Cas 7512-460 
17-6, PN A4106). 461

 463 
 464 
Individual screens 465 
For the individual screens 2 μl of uncorrected spore solution was spotted on 5cm agar plates. And 466 
grown at 30 °C for 10 days.  467 
 468 
Agar excision agar samples 469 
S. coelicolor M145, and Streptomyces species MBT2, MBT5, MBT12, MBT38 and MBT92 with 2*10 6 470 
spores were inoculated on StrepMM Difco with GlcNAc [25 mM] and BHET [10 mM]. After 14 days of 471 
growth, a part of the halo was excised using an agar excision tool. The agar and liquids were 472 
separated using clear spin-filtered microtubes (Sorenson BioSciences) spun at 10.000 rpm for 15 min. 473 
The flow-through was stored at -20 °C and prepared for LC-MS analysis according to the sample 474 
preparation protocol.  475 
 476 
Identification variants Strep strains 477 
For the identification of the Lipase A variants in the Actinobacteria collection genomic DNA of the 478 
active strains was isolated. A PCR was performed using degenerative primers (Table 2) based on the 479 
sequence of the 2lipA gene. PCR was performed with Phusion according to the Phusion protocol 480 
provide by Thermofischer scientific (F531S). The blunt-end PCR products were cloned in pJET2.1 481 
using the CloneJET PCR cloning kit from Thermofischer scientific (K1231).  482 
Table 2:Primers for amplification of Lipase A variants 483
